Not too long ago, two friends of mine were talking to a Cuban refugee, a businessman who had escaped from Castro’s tyranny and built a life for himself in Florida. They asked him about life under Castro. He looked at them with a somber expression and said, "Life under Castro was not easy. We lived in constant fear, with the government controlling every aspect of our lives—from what we could say to how we could earn a living."

This powerful testimony resonates deeply with the spirit of freedom and the struggle for human dignity that we all share. It serves as a stark reminder of the importance of defending our liberties and standing up for those who do not enjoy the same freedoms we do.

In a world where authoritarian regimes still thrive and oppress their people, it is crucial that we, as free citizens, remain vigilant. Our freedoms—freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, and freedom of enterprise—are not just privileges but fundamental rights that we must cherish and protect.

Cuba’s story is one of many where individuals have sought refuge from tyranny, finding a new life in lands that offer hope and opportunity. We must remember that the United States has always been a beacon of hope, a sanctuary for the persecuted, and a haven for those yearning to breathe free.

But the treaty is so much more than that. We must remember that it is a testament to the endurance, resilience, and courage of Indigenous people around the world. It is a living document, a bridge that connects the past with the present and the future. A treaty is not merely a piece of paper with signatures and seals; it is a sacred agreement, a pact that holds the power to shape societies and rebuild broken communities.

For centuries, Indigenous peoples have been custodians of this land, nurturing it with their knowledge, wisdom, and traditions. Treaties serve as a recognition of this deep-rooted connection, acknowledging the historical injustices and seeking a path towards reconciliation and mutual respect. They offer a framework for dialogue, for sharing resources, and for fostering a sense of unity that transcends cultural and geographical boundaries.

The power of a treaty lies in its potential to create lasting change. It can transform policies, promote social equity, and preserve cultural heritage. When we honor a treaty, we are not just fulfilling a legal obligation; we are embracing a moral responsibility. We are committing to a future where Indigenous voices are heard, where their rights are protected, and where their contributions are celebrated.
